title: Saturday March 29th
content: Today was another busy day as a mama of three. Taking Elijah to football Elaina to gymnastics Christopher to jujutsu then grocery shopping picking up stuff for my mom and my grandmother and forgetting about a hair consultation that I had and had to turn around to go back to that consultation, then coming home for like 30 minutes to then take Elaina to a birthday party. Everything was good. I was just tired. My ex-husband called while I was at the birthday party and was making small talk. I told him he could call the boys at home and then he decides to thank me for being a good mom to our children. I’m a little confused about that it’s random.

title: Headache from something so petty
content:
I am annoyed to see that I am living with someone who is supposed to be the man of the house but is not doing what they should do. Anyway, today he's cleaning, and all I said to him was, 'Don't cut down the plant.' He starts acting out and saying to me that I am not the one cleaning it and I am not going to maintain it. I can't understand why it's always a fuss. That fuss gets me so heavy because, as a child growing up, every day there was a fight at my family home. But yet the person I am with tends to love a fuss while saying he doesn't, though he keeps starting it. 
So far I was able to walk away, but the day isn't over he's going to find something else to fuss about. But I will be praying he doesn't. My thing is, he never acknowledges anything good I do. Either he pretends to forget that I am the one who always goes outside and cleans up while still trying to clean inside, or he just doesn't care. I would have our kids outside picking up the leaves that I put in piles to dispose of. But now I am pregnant and unable to do much for myself, yet he forgets that I am always the one trying. He's starting to change me. Or is it that I am starting to see that he just doesn't care about me or my opinion? Because lately, I am still hurt by things he says to me. I am left with a headache in my thoughts, asking myself why he is still with me and always treating me badly why?

recommendations.recommendation: Imagining the worst-case scenarios, such as assuming there will be more conflicts throughout the day. - Practice 'Decatastrophizing' by identifying the worst-case scenario, best-case scenario, and most likely scenario to challenge and balance your thoughts.

Assuming you know what your partner is thinking, such as believing he doesn't care or is intentionally forgetting your efforts. - Use 'Evidence Charting' by writing down evidence for and against these assumptions to develop a more balanced view.

Taking your partner's behavior personally, assuming his actions are a reflection of his feelings toward you. - Practice 'Distancing' by acknowledging that his actions may be influenced by factors unrelated to you and apply a more objective perspective.

content: Today during a team meeting, I presented an idea I was really excited about. But my manager quickly shot it down and moved on without much discussion. I felt embarrassed, like everyone thought it was a dumb suggestion. For the rest of the day, I kept replaying it in my head and wondering if I’m even good at this job. I left work feeling small and discouraged

recommendations.recommendation: Viewing the situation in absolute terms, such as seeing yourself as a complete failure because of one event. - Challenge all-or-nothing thinking by writing down evidence that contradicts this belief. List your accomplishments and positive feedback from others to remind yourself that one meeting does not define your overall competence.

Assuming you know what others are thinking, such as believing everyone thought your idea was dumb. - Practice reality testing by asking yourself: 'What evidence do I have that everyone thought my idea was dumb?' and 'Is there a more balanced way to view the situation?'

Imagining the worst possible outcome, like questioning your competency at your job over a single event. - Use the 'Worst, Best, Most Likely' technique: Write down the worst-case scenario, the best-case scenario, and the most likely outcome. This can help you see the situation more realistically.

title: March 30-31st
content: I’m at the doctors an office in my first day of spring break so not starting in a high note. But last night my mind was racing so much I wanted to journal about it. I let my twins sleep in the room with me and for some reason I kept feeling like I don’t spend enough time with them as I was looking at them. I was wondering if they really know how much I love them. My mind was also racing throughout the night about the relationship I’m in. When we met last year January, I told him I didn’t want a relationship I was still separated from my husband but not divorced yet. He still pursued. We’ve been together ever since then. I feel like it’s been a back and forth battle in my mind ever since. Last night, particularly, I was feeling like this relationship is some how blocking my spiritual relationship. I feel less connected to spiritually. Mostly because we have sex and I grew up believing you are not supposed to have sex outside of marriage. I love him and think he is a wonderful man and great life partner  in many ways but not spiritually. Ironically my ex husband was overly spiritual and pushed his beliefs on me and I hated that. I would really love some peace and clarity. Not to mention good sleep at night.

recommendations.recommendation: The tendency to imagine and believe the worst possible outcome, such as worrying excessively about not spending enough time with the twins and doubting if they know they are loved. - Use the 'Decatastrophizing' technique: Write down the worst-case, best-case, and most realistic scenarios for your concerns about your children. This will help you see that the worst-case scenario is unlikely and provide a more balanced perspective.

Seeing situations in black and white terms, such as viewing the relationship as either entirely good or entirely bad based on spiritual alignment. - Practice 'Cognitive Restructuring': Identify and challenge these black-and-white thoughts by listing positives and negatives of the relationship. Acknowledge the nuance and complexity, which can reduce anxiety about needing everything to be perfect.

Using 'should' statements that reflect rigid rules, like believing one should not have sex outside of marriage, causing guilt and anxiety. - Try the 'Reframing' technique: Replace 'should' statements with more flexible language, such as 'I prefer' or 'I would like to.' This shift can ease the pressure and reduce anxiety associated with rigid beliefs.

title: Travel

recommendations.recommendation: Worrying about future events, such as travel, which disrupts sleep and increases anxiety. - Practice 'worry postponement' by scheduling a specific time earlier in the day to focus on and write down travel-related worries, freeing up mental space at night.

Belief that inadequate sleep will completely ruin the travel experience, increasing stress and anxiety. - Use cognitive restructuring to challenge these thoughts by listing past instances where you managed travel well despite less sleep, proving flexibility in outcomes.

title: On the run
content:
Just  got home from leaving pretty early to attend a funeral this morning.  I was really tired and sleepy.  I had only about 3 hours sleep last night.  After the funeral I ran a few errands including getting my hair did.  

Home now have about an hour to shower eat and get back on the road again to pick up the others from work and school.  Was hoping to be home much earlier to get some rest.

recommendations.recommendation: Imagining the worst-case scenario or exaggerating the potential negative outcomes of being tired and busy. - Practice cognitive restructuring by identifying these thoughts and challenging them with more balanced perspectives. Ask yourself: 'What is the worst that can happen? How would I cope if that happened? What is more likely to happen?'

Viewing the situation in black-and-white terms, such as feeling like the day must be perfect or a failure with no middle ground. - Use a thought record to identify and write down these thoughts. Challenge them by considering the gray areas and acknowledging any small successes or partial achievements throughout the day.

Taking on too many activities or responsibilities without leaving room for rest, leading to overwhelm. - Practice assertiveness training by prioritizing tasks and setting boundaries. Use the 'ABC model' to analyze the situation: identify the Activating event, your Beliefs about it, and the Consequences. Consider delegating tasks or rescheduling to allow time for rest.

came across this story online.
make syou wonder about how the things you do aligns with other
Years ago I found a hefty bag of money - paper money, in the clothes section of a store. I immediately decided, without second thought to hand it in. I came downstairs and saw a few persons working in the stock-room. I handed the money to a guy and told him in the presence of other persons that I just found it upstairs in the clothes section on top of the clothes rack. The guy took the money and I left the store after paying for my purchase. Weeks later, I remembered the incident while speaking to my sister-in-law. Curious, she asked me the name of the store and a description of the person I gave the money to. Unknown to me she did some inquiries and reported back to me. She told me that she knew the guy I gave the money to, and that since then, he started to wear the best of clothes, a change from his former attire, and even later quitted the job.
I reckon it was now her concern; not mine. My conscience was clear.

Granted you do need money to do what you want to do in life and have little luxuries and vacations and buy what you wanna buy, but it gets tiring if that’s the goal, the whole time on the other hand, I need to learn to live with little and shop differently if I’m not going to be making extra money, but there’s this pressure to do it simply because of the person I’m in relationship with so it takes away my motivation to even try because of the pressure. I feel like I get more accomplished and I have better work habits when I’m not dealing with anyone relationship wise, but then loneliness set in and I miss that companionship. So I wonder do you just have to take both and if so, how do you navigate being healthy and hold and picking up good habits while also putting energy into a relationship. Not to mention three children that you’re raising on your own basically. So much to think about but in the end of the day, I and my children have everything we need maybe not everything we want but everything we need.

recommendations.recommendation: Seeing things in black-and-white terms, without considering the middle ground. - Thought Reframing: Find a middle ground by setting small, achievable steps for both personal goals and relationships.
Believing that because you feel something strongly, it must be true. - Gratitude Practice: Shift focus to what you appreciate to counteract feelings of insufficiency.

title: Hello Today, Life Sucks
content:
I am a social worker and every blessed I do nothing but listen to a bunch of ungrateful people complain that life is hard but they don't want to do anything to move their lives forward. What am I doing wrong? Why can't I help them? Why can't get them to understand that life development is a journey that we take together? 

When I look back on my client list, I just shake my head and groan. I mean, I would love to cry but I have no more tears less. Perhaps I need to change my jobs 'cause I really can't take living and working at Ingrate Central anymore. But what can I do? What should I do? I don't have the passion for my work that I used to.

When I first became a social worker it was because I wanted to help people. Now it seems that I am just wasting time because no one wants a hand-up just a handout. What should I do? What do I do now? I am soooooooooooooo tired of everything

Hi there, I can sense the weariness you're feeling from being the one who consistently reaches out to others, only to feel unnoticed when you need support. It sounds like you're experiencing feelings of invisibility, and maybe even questioning if your care for others is misplaced. This is a common feeling when the effort we put into relationships feels unreciprocated. 

Take a moment to reflect on what you truly need from these connections that might not be met right now. Is it recognition, support, or perhaps a deeper sense of connection? 

Remember, your care and kindness are valuable, and they are not diminished by the current imbalance in these relationships. You deserve to be seen and supported, too.

Warmly,
Coach Mira

We're starting to notice a few thought patterns in your journals. Here's what we're seeing:
- All-or-Nothing Thinking
- Mind Reading

structured_data.insight_text: It seems like you're feeling neglected and unimportant in your relationships because your efforts to connect and care are not reciprocated. This might be tied to an emotional need for validation and connection that feels unmet right now.
structured_data.reflection_prompt: Take a moment. When you feel invisible despite your care for others, does it remind you of patterns from your past relationships?

strategies.title: Communication Script Template
strategies.description: Use this script to express your feelings and needs in conversations.
strategies.action_step: I feel unimportant when my efforts aren't reciprocated because it leaves me feeling unseen. What I need is more mutual support.

strategies.title: Reality-Check Exercise
strategies.description: Challenge the assumption that you are not important to others by examining evidence.
strategies.action_step: List evidence for and against the belief that your care is unnoticed.

relationship_questions: When you feel invisible despite your care for others, does it remind you of patterns from your past relationships?
structured_data.followup_text: Remember, your feelings of invisibility are valid, but they don't define your worth. Try using the communication script to express your needs in a way that opens up a dialogue for mutual support.
